Act Like an Optimist , Improve Your Health

items.teaser: Is the glass of your life half-full or half-empty? Take this quiz to discover your everyday attitude.
items.sub_heading: Is the glass of your life half-full or half-empty? Because whether you realize it or not, your deal-with-it style affects your workday, home life and time with the kids. Take this quiz by Amy Spencer, author of Bright Side Up: 100 Ways to Be Happier Right Now, to see where your mind-set falls—and learn how balancing a little of the other attitudes on your shoulders can make life better all around.
items.description: Is the glass of your life half-full or half-empty? Take this quiz to discover your everyday attitude.
items.title: Quiz: Are You an Optimist, Realist or Cynic?
items.meta_title: Optimist, Realist or Cynic Quiz - What's Your Attitude

result.result_additional_text: You are an optimist. You’re able to see the bright side of even the most challenging situations, and you don’t assume that failures are your fault or that issues can’t be worked out. Keep up your positive thinking! Just remember to remove the rose-colored glasses when something in your career, marriage or home life really isn’t working so you can get your hands in there to fix it.

You’ve mastered the balance of a realist! You can see both sides of most situations and choose to come at it from the most practical one—because, hey, life is hard, and it’s our job to barrel through it. So keep being real. Just remember to give other people—and yourself—the benefit of the doubt sometimes. If you look for the positive angle of a challenging situation, you might feel better about it without actually having to change a single thing.

You’re pretty good at sighing as a cynic! What’s the point in sugar-coating life, right? And you probably get people laughing with your snarky sense of humor. Just remember that a few negative opinions can sometimes add up to a big bummer vibe. We’re not suggesting pom-poms and kitten posters to be more positive; just look for the humor in bad situations. Life isn’t just what happens to us, it’s also how we see it—and that’s one thing that’s all up to you.

question.question_text: After three interviews, you didn’t get the job. You think:

answer.answer_text: A. There must have been an applicant with more hands-on experience than me.
B. Times are tough. I can’t expect to get every job.
C. They obviously just want “Yes men” to do their bidding, which I’ll never do.

question.question_text: At a restaurat, the crab cakes come to the table looking worse than what you expected. You think:

answer.answer_text: A. Every restaurant makes them their own way, maybe these are good.
B. I guess I should have asked how they make them before I ordered them.
C. I should’ve known not to order crab cakes outside of Baltimore.

question.question_text: Your husband’s parents are coming to visit, and your pushy mother-in-law is always a nightmare. This year you:

answer.answer_text: A. Decide to try a new tack and ask for her opinion before she gives it. Maybe this will work.
B. Brace for the assault, planning to just grin and bear it.
C. Beg your husband to shorten their visit. If it’s going to be hell, you want it to be a shorter hell.

question.question_text: At your dinner party, you mis-timed the roast chicken and now it’s as dry as a saltine cracker. You:

answer.answer_text: A. Welcome everyone to your first annual meatless chicken dinner and offer a prize to the person who comes up with the best use for twelve pounds of poultry jerky.
B. Apologize to the table and offer extra gravy to anyone who dares try the bird.
C. Choke back tears as you curse Murphy’s Law—of course you put out your worst meal on party night.

question.question_text: Your kid’s teacher is recommending a special reading class. You think:

answer.answer_text: A. I wouldn’t think my child would need it, but whatever helps him excel...
B. “Special?” We need to talk about this first.
C. Oh, that’s ridiculous. Those teachers never know what they’re talking about.

question.question_text: On vacation, the cab broke down so you missed your flight, and now your hotel says they gave away your room and will find you another. You:

answer.answer_text: A) Think, “Are you kidding me?! Well, one more disaster and this will really get funny.”
B. Take a deep breath, ask for the hotel manager and beg your way to a better room at the next place.
C. Start yelling—your whole vacation is ruined and that’s absolutely unacceptable.

question.question_text: You hear about a big party you weren’t invited to. You think:

answer.answer_text: A. “I’m sure she just forgot to add me to the list.”
B. “Parties are personal, she can’t invite everyone.”
C. “She probably did it on purpose because of that comment I made last month.”

question.question_text: Your boss assigns you the task of pitching a product better than the other eight in the market. You say:

answer.answer_text: A. “Well, let’s see what we’ve got that they don’t!”
B. “Couldn’t our skills be used elsewhere, to create something brand new instead?”
C. “You’re kidding, right? Number nine?”

question.question_text: Your little one doesn’t want to eat the Brussels sprouts. You think:

answer.answer_text: A. I’ll try again next week. Eventually my kid’s palate will get used to it and like them as much as I do.
B. Well, there’s another vegetable I might have to knock off the list.
C. Of course she hates them, she’s a kid. Why did I bother trying to serve something other than mac and cheese?

question.question_text: Your husband walks into the house brooding, then slips into the den without saying a word to you. You:

answer.answer_text: A. Give him his fifteen minutes to calm down, because it’s probably not about you.
B. Wonder what you’ve done to make him so mad. In a few minutes, you’ll ask.
C. Think, "Men always do this" and then eat the cookie you bought him at the store.

question.question_text: Your friend just cancelled your lunch date for the second time this month. You think:

answer.answer_text: A. “Life happens. Let’s put it back on the calendar for next week and try one last time"
B. “It’s obviously not a good time for her, so I’ll let her get in touch eventually when she can squeeze it in.”
C. “I don’t know why I bother making plans with people, they always cancel.”

question.question_text: You accidentally set your alarm for p.m. instead of a.m. and by the time you wake up, you’re 30 minutes late for work! What do you say to yourself?

answer.answer_text: A. "At least there won’t be rush hour traffic and this is the one morning I don’t have a big meeting."
B. "Argh, I can’t believe I did that! I’ll just do a mad catch up as soon as I get there."
C. "I’m such an idiot! Now my whole day is going to be behind and messed up."

items.teaser: Esquire Russia takes us inside the protests, rallies, and arrests that have rocked Moscow
items.sub_heading: With Vladimir Putin expected to return as Russia's president following this weekend's controversial election, the editor of Esquire Russia, along with a fellow journalist, takes us inside the protests, rallies, and arrests that rocked Moscow and made for some very strange days
items.description: Esquire Russia takes us inside the protests, rallies, and arrests that have rocked Moscow
items.title: What the Hell Is Happening in Russia?
items.meta_title: Russia 2012 Elections - Russian Political Protests and Arrests
items.body:
Published in the March 2012 issue

DECEMBER 4, 2011: Voting Station No. 1 in the center of Moscow, across the street from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs building, 8:30 A.M., half an hour after voting in the most explosive parliamentary election in the history of New Russia began: An independent observer is removed by the election committee because he "took pictures and asked questions." Nobody seems to care too much about this incident: not the voters waiting in line, not the police who escort the observer from the premises, not even the other observers — the very people who are supposed to ensure a fair and open election on behalf of the media and various participating political parties.

More than a thousand miles away, well before the first vote was even cast, the authorities of Levoberezhnaya District in North Ossetia had a simple plan for how the elections would turn out. United Russia, the ruling party and the political instrument by which Vladimir Putin (and, nominally, Dmitry Medvedev) has exercised total control over the state for the past twelve years, was supposed to get about 74 percent at each voting station; the Communist party, the always-second main rival of UR, was supposed to get around 20 percent. And so they do in most of the district, except where heads of several voting commissions give 74 percent to the Communists and 20 percent to UR. The only reasonable explanation: They mixed up their instructions, attributed the wrong percentages to the wrong parties, and revealed that the fix was in from the very beginning.

Weird things happen all over the country. In Chechnya, according to official results, voter attendance is 99.5 percent, and yet according to the preelection polls, more than 60 percent of the people in the republic said they never or almost never vote. In Moscow, two voting stations in the same school report vastly different findings — one has 90 percent for United Russia, the other only 26 percent. Independent observers in Russia's capital who weren't removed from voting stations tell incredible stories about election officials who escape the stations with bags full of ballots — never to be seen at the station again. Ilya Azar, a correspondent for the news site Lenta.ru, manages to go undercover with two other journalists to reveal a fraud scheme called the "merry-go-round": People are hired to go around to several voting stations with falsified absentee ballots, and with the help of local election commissions, they stuff the ballot boxes. This is either the sloppiest case of election rigging in history or proof that some acts of fraud are simply too massive to succeed.

By nightfall it becomes clear that United Russia will carry the day and retain control of parliament, but by a much slimmer margin than anybody expected. People start to read about allegations of fraud and abuse. On blogs. On Facebook. They watch videos on YouTube that document ballot stuffing. They question whether United Russia would have prevailed in a free and fair election. They question how far Putin and Medvedev will go to stay in power. And for the first time in a long time, some of them decide to do something about it.

DECEMBER 5: Thousands of people, perhaps as many as ten thousand, gather in the center of Moscow, on Chistoprudny Boulevard, to protest election fraud. It is the largest gathering of protesters in a decade, and among them is Alexei Navalny, a lawyer, political activist, and blogger who became famous last year when he branded United Russia "the party of crooks and thieves." Navalny gets up onstage and makes a speech, most notable for the remark: "They call us little hamsters from the social networks. Yes, I am a little network hamster! And I'll gnaw through the throats of these cads!" — meaning the regime. "It was clear that we couldn't just stand there for a while and leave," says Navalny. "We needed some act of civil disobedience that said: We exist. So some people decided to go to the Central Election Commission building, which was about a mile away. The first couple of cordons were pretty easy to pass — internal troops, silly little soldiers with their silly shields: You push him, and he either falls down or steps aside. But then came the OMON, special-purpose police units. Those guys are pretty big and well trained, they stand in two rows, and they know how to hit you — first a real tricky one with a knee, then with their helmet. I got one right on my nose. If you want to break a cordon like that, you must have tenfold the people, which we actually had, but we were too spread out. So we didn't get to the CEC building — they just squeezed us in and packed us into buses." The police arrest several hundred people, Navalny among them, who goes on to serve fifteen days in prison for "disobedience to the police." "The overall mood at the rally was aggressive," Navalny told us a few days after he was released. "Of the seventy detainees who were arrested after the rally, 80 percent were observers at the elections. They were expelled from their voting stations, they witnessed ballot stuffing and all kinds of fraud, and they came to the rally not to support any oppositional party, association, or person — they came because they were filled with very personal, furious rage."
items.in_this_issue_text: With Vladimir Putin expected to return as Russia's president following this month's controversial election, the editor of Esquire Russia, along with a fellow journalist, takes us inside the protests, rallies, and arrests that rocked Moscow and made for some very strange days

items.description: Boob-bounce getting in the way of your exercise performance? Do you find yourself wearing an extra tight top in an attempt to keep them in place? We’ll bet you didn’t know that your unsupported breasts could be bouncing up to fourteen centi
items.title: Win a Shock Absorber Sports Bra
items.meta_title: Win a Shock Absorber Sports Bra
items.body:
We’re on a mission to get all you exercise-loving girls into the right kit. No, we don’t mean skin-light lycra shorts or wind-resistant tops. It’s the first layer that really matters. That’s right – your bra. Get the right one and you can confidently run (or volley, jump, or box) your way to a great body, without damaging your breasts as you go.

That might sound crazy, but the very things you do to tone and improve the rest of your body can be doing the opposite to your boobs if you’re not supporting them. You probably know that there are no muscles in our breasts (if there were we’d have boob-gyms instead of have uplift bras and implants!). Our breasts are actually held in shape by delicate ligaments, and once they have been stretched beyond their limit no amount of toning exercises can improve them.

You might think that your normal bra is going to do the job when you work out but it’s just not true. Did you know that a Shock Absorber sports bra is twice as effective at preventing bounce as your everyday bra that you might be wearing at the gym? What’s more, sports bras are designed to help you get the most from your workout, with shaped, padded straps that won’t keep falling down and performance fabrics that make sure you stay cooler and drier.

Get the right sports bra and you’ll wonder how you ever managed without it.

So, it’s time to get your hands on one of the brilliant Shock Absorber sports bras. These exercise-essentials can reduce bounce by up to a whopping 78%*

Made from moisture-wicking, breathable, sports performance fabrics, they’ll also keep you super comfortable as you workout. If you are a runner you definitely need the Ultimate Run Bra, which includes a seamless inner to reduce friction, and padded no-slip straps. Like a bit of shape and oomph? Go for the Sports Padded Bra; removable pads and a soft, non-rub hook and eye fastening make this stylish sports bra a popular choice.

Those of you who like lower-cut tops, or just want to feel cooler – will love the Sports Plunge Bra, with its plunging front mesh panel for extra cooling and sleek racer back for ease of movement (a great yoga piece). If you do a variety of sports you will want the Multi-Sports Support Bra, it looks like a crop top so you can wear it under your gym kit or on its own, but it’s super supportive thanks to an inner bra construction. And it goes up to a HH cup too!

Still not sure which sports bra is for you? Take our picture quiz to find out!

Lucky for you, the UK’s leading sports bra brand, Shock Absorber are giving away 10 of their must-have sports bras. For your chance to win, simply click here.

items.teaser: Workouts nine and ten of James King’s 12-week muscle-building plan
items.sub_heading: Workouts nine and ten of James King’s 12-week muscle-building plan
items.description: The complete beginner’s muscle-building programme #5. Personal trainer James King’s 12-week plan will take you from skinny gym newbie to stacked veteran. Here are your workouts for week 9
items.title: The complete beginner's muscle-building programme #5
items.meta_title: The complete beginner’s muscle-building programme #5. Personal trainer James King’s 12-week plan will take you from skinny gym newbie to stacked veteran. Here are your workouts for week 9
items.body:
Utilising simple moves that are easy to perform, James King's beginner's training plan is ideal for those new to the gym.

This is a 12-week muscle-building programme. Click here for weeks 1-2, here for weeks 3-4, here for weeks 5-6, here for weeks 7-8 and finish up with weeks 11-12.

If you are unsure about a technical term, simply click on the blue highlighted text for a full explanation.

Your instructions

Week 9

Sets per exercise 4
Reps per exercise 10
Exercise tempo 2-1-3-1
Rest between supersets 60 seconds
Suggested weight 75-80% of your one-rep max (the most you can lift for one repetition; learn how to calculate yours here)

Perform each pair of moves as supersets, with no rest between the two exercises.

Week 10 progression Reduce your rest between each superset to 30 seconds.

Workout A

Muscles targeted Chest, shoulders and triceps

Warm-up move: Deadlift and box jump supersets

How to do the deadlift With your feet flat beneath a barbell, squat down and grasp it with your hands roughly shoulder-width apart – one hand facing away from you, one facing towards you. Keep your chest up, pull your shoulders back and look straight ahead as you lift the bar, keeping it close to your legs. Focus on taking the weight back onto your heels (rather than your toes). Lift to thigh level, pause, then return very slowly to the start position.

Be sure to ask a personal trainer or gym instructor to check your technique and form if you’re unsure.

How to do the box jump Stand in front of a sturdy, secure box that requires a high-effort jump. Your feet should be shoulder-width apart. Leap up onto the box with a soft landing. Step down and reset your feet. If you find the move too challenging, reduce the jump height or step up rather than jump.

Muscle builder 1: Barbell bench press and hand-release press-up supersets

How to do the barbell bench press Lie flat on the bench with your eyes underneath the bar. Grab it with an overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Take a deep breath, tighten your core, then exhale and press the bar from the rack until your arms are fully extended. Pause at the top for a second, take another deep breath, hold it, then lower until the barbell touches your chest. Exhale and drive the bar back to the top phase of the movement. Repeat.

How to do the hand-release press-up Lie flat on the floor, face down, with your hands placed shoulder-width apart at chest height. Take a deep breath, then exhale as you push up away from the floor until your arms are fully extended. Your body should be straight from shoulders to ankles. Lower to the floor until you’re in the start position, lift your hands away from the floor. And repeat.

Muscle builder 2: Overhead tricep press and tricep dip supersets

How to do the overhead tricep press This exercise mimics the movement of a football throw in. Stand facing away from a cable column, grab the rope/bar with an overhand grip, and hold it behind your head. Step forward with one foot to provide support and bend your body forward at your hip to ana ngle of about 30 degrees. This is your start position. You should now be able to push forward with your forearms until your arms are fully extended and parallel with the floor. Maintain an upward gaze with your elbows narrow and pointing forward throughout. Return under control to the start position. And repeat.

How to do the tricep dip Place your hands on two parallel bars and lift yourself up so your shoulders are directly above your hands with your chest is raised. Lower your body under control until your shoulders are lower than the elbows – or as far as your flexibility allows. Then push back up to the start position. Keep your eyes and chest up throughout the movement. Assistance from a machine (which you place your knees on) or a training partner can be used if necessary.

Muscle builder 3: Pec deck and box jumps supersets

How to use the pec deck Sit up straight with your back and head rested against the pec deck bench (it’s this one). When holding the two handles with arms outstretched to your sides, your upper arms should be angled very slightly lower than horizontal, with your forearms and fists facing towards the ceiling – almost forming a right angle with the rest of your arm. From here, squeeze your elbows together until they make contact, pause for a second, then very slowly allow them to return to the start position. Keep your head up throughout.

How to do the box jump See above.

Fat Burner: Rowing machine intervals

Tabata row Row as fast as you can for 20 seconds. Recover for 10 seconds. Repeat for eight rounds.

Workout B

Muscles targeted Back and biceps

Warm-up move: Back squat and tricep press-up supersets

How to do the squat Approach the squat rack with the bar set to upper chest height. With your feet shoulder-width apart and toes facing slightly outwards, grip the barbell with a slightly wider than shoulder-width grip. Crouch down to place your shoulders underneath the bar and push up to dismount it from the rack. Take a deep breath in, keeping your core very tight, and lower your hips back and down until they are at least as low as your knees. Push back to the start position along the same path. Ensure your heels are flat on the floor, your knees are pointing outward, your back is straight, and your chest is up at all times.

How to do the tricep press-up Lie flat on the floor, face down, with your hands positioned so your index fingers and thumbs touch in a diamond shape below the centre of your chest. Take a deep breath, then exhale as you push up away from the floor until your arms are fully extended. Your body should be straight from shoulders to ankles. Lower until you are an inch from the floor. And repeat.

Muscle builder 1: Lat pull down and underarm pull up supersets

How to do the lat pull down Sit facing the lat pull down station and grab the bar with an overhand wide grip. Keeping your head up and your back straight, pull the bar down and stick your chest out so that the bar touches (or comes close to touching) the top of your chest. Pause. Then slowly reverse the movement until your arms are fully extended. Repeat.

How to do the underarm pull up Grab the bar with an underarm grip and pull upward until your chin reaches the top of the bar. Then slowly lower back down until your arms are fully extended. Repeat. If this is too difficult use an assisted machine, placing your knees on the platform.

Muscle builder 2: Barbell bicep curl and medicine-ball hammer curl supersets

How to do the barbell bicep curl Stand holding a barbell using an underhand grip with the weight in contact with your thighs. Keep your arms tight to your body and bend at your elbows to curl the bar up until it makes contact with your chest. Pause and return very slowly to the start position. Be careful not to let your elbows creep forward as you curl the bar upwards.

How to do the medicine-ball hammer curl Stand holding a medicine ball with your palms facing towards your body. Bend at your elbows, keeping your upper arms dead straight, to bring your forearms towards your shoulders. Flex hard at the top of the movement then lower back to the start position. Repeat.

Muscle builder 3: Seated row and bear walk supersets

How to do the seated row Sit down with your feet flat on the floor. Your knees should be slightly bent, your back upright and your chest high. Tip forward at the hips and grasp the bar. Now pull back, bending your elbows and keeping them tight to your body. Very slowly return to the start position. Repeat.

How to do the bear walk Bend your knees until you are able to touch the floor with both hands. Now walk forward using your hands until you are in the top phase of a press-up. Pause here and return to the start position. Keep your abs tight and eyes looking upwards throughout the movement.

Fat burner: 10% incline treadmill tabata

Run as fast as you can for 20 seconds. Recover for 10 seconds. Repeat for eight rounds.

If your wedding shoe dreams are in glorious technicolour rather than shades of white, Emmy’s new Wish List collection is for you.

Allowing brides (or maids and mums) to create their own custom footwear, Emmy gives you a choice of shoe shapes, heel heights, rainbow colours and exquisite hand-finished decorative details. You can then mix and match to your heart’s content 'til you’ve styled-up your perfect W-day shoe.

One VIP family have already had a preview of this exclusive service - Emmy have made bespoke pieces for the Duchess of Cambridge, her sister Pippa Middleton and their mother Carole Middleton.

The service starts at £350 and is available from the Emmy studio at 65 Cross Street, London N1 2BB or online at emmyshoes.co.uk.

items.teaser: This fast dinner recipe for Primavera Couscous Salad will have dinner on the table in 25 minutes.
items.description: This fast dinner recipe for Primavera Couscous Salad will have dinner on the table in 25 minutes.
items.title: Easy Weeknight Meal: Primavera Couscous Salad
items.meta_title: Primavera Couscous Salad Recipe - Fast Dinner Recipes

blog_element.paragraph:
¼ cup olive oil

1 (6-oz) box pearled couscous

2 cups low-sodium vegetable broth

1 can lentils or chickpeas (about 15 oz), rinsed, drained

½ cup diced red onion

1 tsp each kosher salt and freshly ground pepper

1 each large zucchini and yellow summer squash, halved down the middle, sliced

1 pint mixed cherry tomatoes, halved

1 cup shredded carrots

Grated zest and juice of 1 lemon (1 tsp zest, 3 Tbsp juice)

2 bunches watercress

1 (4-oz) log fresh goat cheese,

coarsely crumbled

½ cup coarsely chopped salted pistachios

 

1. Heat 1 Tbsp of the oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat; add couscous and stir. Cook until couscous becomes lightly browned, 2 to 3 minutes. Slowly add broth, stir, and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium and simmer, uncovered, until couscous is tender and most of the broth has evaporated, 8 to 10 minutes. Remove from heat and drain in a colander. Transfer couscous to a large bowl and stir in lentils, red onion, and ½ tsp each of the salt and pepper.

 

2. Heat 1 Tbsp of the oil in a nonstick skillet over high heat. Add zucchini and squash and sauté 3 minutes, until crisp-tender. Add to couscous along with tomatoes, carrots, lemon zest and juice, and the remaining 2 Tbsp of the oil, and gently toss to dress.

 

3. Arrange watercress on plates and top with couscous mixture. Sprinkle with goat cheese and pistachios.

 

Makes 4 servings. Each serving: 616 cal, 31 g fat, 24 g protein, 67 g carb.

items.keywords: shopping
items.teaser: If you have a big presentation or high-pressure meeting coming up and need a boost of confidence, why not look to your wardrobe for some help?
items.sub_heading: For Catherine Hageman, the voice behind Small Town, Big Wardrobe, big-day outfits are classic with a twist.
items.description: For Catherine Hageman, the voice behind Small Town, Big Wardrobe, big-day outfits are classic with a twist.
items.title: The Perfect Confidence-Boosting Outfit
items.meta_title: Big Day Outfit - Confidence Boosting Clothes

blog_element.paragraph:
If you have a big presentation or high-pressure meeting coming up and need a boost of confidence, why not look to your wardrobe for some help?

I often leave it to my clothes to jumpstart my confidence. Even when I'm stressed, the perfect outfit can kick away most of my nerves and lead the way to a brighter day at work.

Whether I'm giving a presentation, attending a big meeting or just need a little boost, I always reach for a certain look: bright colors, some sparkles and a fun necklace (or two), and I'm ready to tackle any PowerPoint.

I tend to keep presentation outfits classic with a twist — pencil skirts are part of my work uniform, but I make them edgier by choosing neon colors. Clothes really do affect on my mood, and who can be nervous when wearing a neon pink skirt?

The pieces I chose to pair with my skirt also set the stage for my day. I feel like I've mentioned blazers in almost every post, but with good reason: they exude knowledge and confidence, and help complete many outfits. The finishing touch is favorite silver-and-pearls multi-strand necklace.

Sometimes when you're nervous, faking self-assuredness is half the battle won. An outfit that makes you feel good goes a long way, too.

Blazer, Target; T-shirt, Target; skirt, J. Crew; necklace, Simply Vera Vera Wang for Kohl's; tights, Target; heels, Target

Catherine Hageman dispatches fashionista tendencies fit for a corporate career on Small Town, Big Wardrobe.

blog_element.paragraph:
My husband, Todd, has gotten in the habit of giving me art whenever a special occasion warrants it. Last Mother's Day he gifted me a sweet little print, framed in white, that I hung on the wall under my kitchen cabinets. It's a colorful print of a collection of cookbooks, including some of my favorites. It's always right there, when I'm chopping vegetables or throwing ingredients in the slow cooker, reminding me of how well he knows me, even better than I know myself sometimes. I love it.

So when I decided it was time for another giveaway, I wanted one of you to have one, too. The 8 x 10 print that I'm giving away, shown above, is one of  Jane Mount's Ideal Bookshelf series. The series is full of bookshelves: a shelf of Jane Austin titles, fashion books, Twilight books and more. For a more extravagant gift($220–$280, depending on the size), the artist will make a custom print of your favorite bookshelf. Cool stuff, especially for a book lover.

If you love cookbooks or unique artwork, enter for a chance to win the print shown above. To enter, just tell us, in the comments section below, what's on your ideal bookshelf (cookbooks or other). Make sure you leave a valid e-mail address where requested so I can contact you if you win. The complete giveaway rules are here.

items.meta_title: Gwyneth Paltrow Oscar Makeup - Get Gwyneth Paltrow's Academy Award Look

blog_element.paragraph:
Is it me, or is Gwyneth Paltrow always at least three steps ahead of the trend curve? Just when I think I’m on to her, she shows up to the Oscars in the most sophisticated, jaw-dropping white dress — with a CAPE — and subtle, bronze makeup. Anyone else would’ve smoked out her eyes or donned a red lip, but not Gwynnie. She’s one of kind.

Of course, Mrs. Coldplay can’t take all the credit. Her NARS makeup artist, Leslie Lopez, created the sun-kissed, almost monochromatic look, which I will be copying as soon as the weather warms up. Here’s how it’s done:

Face: NARS Pure Radiant Tinted Moisturizer SPF 30/PA+++ (just out and it’s amazing), with Super Orgasm Illuminator patted onto the apples of the cheeks.

Eyes: The champagne side of NARS Alhambra Duo Eyeshadow applied on the eyelid for a pop of gold, followed by Maybelline brown liquid eyeliner along the lash line and NARS Larger Than Life Volumizing Mascara.

Lips: NARS Odalisque Larger Than Life Lip Gloss, a creamy peach shade.

Elizabeth Dehn is the editor-in-chief of Beauty Bets, an award-winning blog chock-full of product reviews, wellness tips, and DIY ideas.

items.promo_title: Stephanie Cutter: "I Know How to Throw a Punch"

related_links_list.link_text: Stephanie Cutter : "I Know How to Throw a Punch"

items.teaser: Behind the buttery highlights and geek glasses is one of the fiercest strategists in politics. Meet the Obama campaign's head rumor-killer, message-crafter, and human bulldozer.
items.sub_heading: Behind the buttery highlights and geek glasses is one of the fiercest strategists in politics. Meet the Obama campaign's head rumor-killer, message-crafter, and human bulldozer.
items.description: Behind the buttery highlights and geek glasses is one of the fierces strategists in politics. Meet the Obama campaign's head rumor-killer, message-crafter, and human bulldozer.
items.title: Stephanie Cutter: "I Know How to Throw a Punch"
items.meta_title: Stephanie Cutter Interview - Obama's Deputy Campaign Manager Stephanie Cutter
items.body:
There are moments on the campaign trail when everything goes wrong. An attack takes the candidate unawares. One adviser is on a plane and unreachable, while two others are feuding about whether to ignore the charge or beat it back. Meanwhile, the press is demanding answers and sounding alarms. The campaign is in free fall.

It's for just these moments that a campaign keeps an enforcer on hand: someone fearless and unflappable, someone who will step up, take charge, and, if needed, take the blame. For President Barack Obama, that someone is Stephanie Cutter.

Cutter, 43, a deputy campaign manager for Obama-Biden 2012, has been with the Obamas since 2008, when she started out as Michelle's chief of staff, and is one of the most respected communications strategists in Washington. "Politics gets me out of bed in the morning," she tells Marie Claire at her office in Obama's Chicago re-election headquarters. "It's what really interests me. I'm a competitor, but I also feel like I'm contributing, whether it's working on health-care policy in the White House or out here in Chicago."

Having just moved out from Washington a week before, she is already knee-deep in the hour-to-hour mini crises that define campaign life. She doesn't get home to her newly rented apartment until 9 or 10 p.m. (Cutter is unmarried; her dog, a rescue named Sammy, has a dog walker.) She grabs a few hours' sleep, rises at 5 a.m., and gets in a quick workout. Then it all starts again.

Asked how she's made it to the highest ranks of politics — in 2012, still a boys' club packed with locker-room personalities — Cutter demures. "I have no idea how it happened," she says with a little laugh. "I know I worked hard." (An associate, on the other hand, knows exactly how she did it: "She's a bulldozer when she needs to be.")

Cutter grew up in a politically active family in Raynham, Massachusetts, where she and her two brothers were treated as equals. "My brother got a .22 for his 12th birthday; I got a .22. He got a hunting knife; I got a hunting knife," Cutter says. Her attraction to public service goes back as long as she can remember. In high school, she canvassed the lunchroom for donations for the famine in Ethiopia. She graduated from Smith College, where she was also politically active. (Her college pal Julianna Smoot is one of two other deputy campaign managers for Obama.)

After graduating, Cutter marched into the offices of New York Governor Mario Cuomo, an idol of hers who was considering a presidential run of his own, and cold-pitched his staff on hiring her. "And that was my first job: answering his phones," she says. Soon she was promoted to speechwriter, and when Cuomo bowed out of the 1992 presidential race, she was snapped up by Bill Clinton's campaign. Afterward, she worked as a spokeswoman at the Environmental Protection Agency — which at the time was under assault from then Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich — and eventually worked her way up to deputy communications director at the White House, where she handled President Clinton's daily message.
